questions.text: Which of the following subtypes of HIV is most common in India?
questions.solution:
Subtype C of HIV is the most common in India. It causes more than 95% of HIV infections.  

Subtypes A and C are more readily transmitted by heterosexual contact than subtype B, which is mainly transmitted by homosexual contact and injections.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about HIV?
questions.solution:
HIV is a thermolabile virus. It is readily inactivated by heating to 60 °C for 10 minutes and at 100 °C in seconds. At room temperature (20–25 °C) in the dried blood, it may survive for 1 week.

Option A: HIV crosses the blood-brain barrier. It may cause encephalopathy leading to loss of higher functions, progressing to dementia.

Option B: HIV is a spherical, enveloped virus. Its genome is composed of two copies of identical single-stranded positive-sense RNA.

Option C: HIV is inactivated by treatment with 0.3% hydrogen peroxide, 50% ethanol, 35% isopropanol or 10% household bleach. A 2% solution of glutaraldehyde is effective for the disinfection of medical instruments.

questions.text: Which of the following is a nonstructural gene of HIV?
questions.solution:
The tat gene (trans-activating gene) is a non-structural gene. 

HIV has structural and non-structural genes: 

  • Structural genes- Genes coding for structural protiens:  
    • gag- Codes for core and shell protein p55, which is cleaved to p15, p18 and p24  
    • env- Codes for envelope glycoprotein gp160 which is cleaved to gp120 and gp41
    • pol- Codes for enzymes: Polymerase, reverse transcriptase, protease and endonuclease
  • Non-structural and regulatory genes:
    • tat- Trans-activating gene
    • nef- Negative factor gene
    • rev- Regulator of virus gene
    • vif- Viral infectivity factor gene
    • vpu- (only in HIV-1) and vpx (only in HIV-2)
    • vpr- Stimulates only the promoter region of the virus
    • LTR- Long terminal repeat sequences

questions.text: Which of the following represents the correct sequence of HIV replication?
questions.solution:
HIV replicates by the sequence RNA-DNA-RNA. The provirus initiates viral replication by directing the synthesis of viral RNA and other components. Hence, the sequence is RNA–ssDNA–dsDNA–RNA. 

HIV genome is composed of 2 single-stranded positive-sense RNA. When a virus infects a cell, the viral RNA is transcribed by the enzyme reverse transcriptase, first into single-stranded DNA and then to double-stranded DNA which is integrated into the host chromosome.

Note: If the options include RNA-DNA-RNA and RNA-DNA-DNA-RNA then the latter would be the choice.

questions.text: As part of developing the public health policy on HIV in India, which of the following modes of transmission would you focus on the most?
questions.solution:
Heterosexual transmission is the most common mode of transmission of HIV infection in developing countries such as India and African countries. In many Western countries, male-to-male sexual transmission is the dominant mode of transmission. 

Blood transfusion carries the highest risk per 10000 exposures of getting HIV from an infected person. However, it is not the most common mode of transmission.

questions.text: A 35-year-old bisexual man goes to an ICTC centre for counselling about HIV. Which of the following is false about HIV transmission?

choices.text: Male-to-female HIV transmission has more risk of causing infection than female-to-male transmission
The risk of acquiring HIV with unprotected receptive anal intercourse is lower than that with penile-vaginal intercourse
The quantity of HIV-1 in plasma is a primary determinant of the risk of HIV-1 transmission
Male circumcision is associated with a lower risk of HIV acquisition for heterosexual men

questions.solution:
The risk of HIV acquisition associated with unprotected receptive anal intercourse is relatively higher than that seen in penile-vaginal intercourse. This is because the rectal mucosal membrane is thin and fragile and anal intercourse is associated with microtrauma (rectal tears). 

The differences in transmission rates between men and women are because the vagina and cervix are exposed to semen for a longer duration, increasing the risk of transmission. However, the penis and urethral orifice are exposed relatively briefly to infected vaginal fluid, lowering the risk.

questions.text: Specific binding of the HIV to the CD4 receptor occurs via which of these?
questions.solution:
The specific binding of the HIV to the CD4 receptor is by the envelope glycoprotein gp120.

Option B - Cell fusion occurs via binding to gp41. Cell fusion is essential for infection to take place.

Option C, D - Binding to CD4 receptor requires the participation of a co-receptor CXCR 4 for T cell tropic HIV strains and CCR 5 for macrophage-tropic strains.

questions.text: A patient presents to you with a history of sharing needles during IV drug abuse with an HIV-positive partner. HIV-antibody spot test was negative, however p24 antigen assay was positive. You explain to him that he is currently in the window period for HIV. Which of the following statements would you use to explain the concept to him?

choices.text: It is the time period between infection and onset of first symptoms
It is the time period between infection and detection of antibodies
It is the time period between exposure and onset of viral multiplication
It is the time period between exposure and appearance of symptoms

questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the patient has experienced a high-risk exposure to HIV due to sharing needles during IV drug abuse with an HIV-positive partner. 

The period between infection and detection of antibodies against HIV is known as the window period.

The window period may last anywhere between 2–8 weeks to a few months. During this period, the individual may be highly infectious. HIV infection can be detected during this period by p24 antigen assay and PCR.

questions.text: A 41-year-old man was admitted for hernioplasty and initial investigations revealed that he is HIV-positive. He gives no history of contact and has no HIV-associated symptoms.  Which of the following statements is incorrect about this phase of HIV infection?

choices.text: Rapid decline of CD4 count is common

questions.solution:
The given patient is in the latent period of HIV infection. During the latent phase of HIV infection, the CD4+ T cell count declines steadily and not rapidly.

All patients infected with HIV pass through a phase of clinical latency during which they are asymptomatic. This can last for years. During the latent phase, patients show positive HIV antibody tests and they are infectious. There will be varying degrees of viral multiplication.

Throughout the course of untreated infection and even during the stage of clinical latency, HIV is actively replicating or is sequestered in lymphoid tissues.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents to the clinic requesting an HIV test. He had unprotected sexual contact with another man 3 weeks ago. Antibodies against which of the following will be detected first by ELISA or Western blot?
questions.solution:
Antibodies against gp41 will be detected first by ELISA or Western blot. 

Antibodies to HIV usually appear within 3–6 weeks of primary infection. The appearance of HIV-binding antibodies occurs prior to the appearance of neutralizing antibodies. The only viral proteins that elicit neutralizing antibodies are the envelope proteins gp120 and gp41.

The order of appearance of antibodies is as follows:

Antibody to envelope gp41 > Antibodies to gag protein (p24 and p55) > Antibodies to envelope gp120 > Antibodies to gag protein p17 > Antibodies to pol gene products (p31 and p66).

Note: The earliest antigen to appear in the blood following HIV infection is p24.

questions.text: You are an officer with the Center for Disease Control and are screening a high-risk population for HIV. Which of the following methods will you use as a screening tool?
questions.solution:
ELISA is most commonly used as a screening test for HIV. 

Screening tests possess high sensitivity but are not highly specific. ELISA is a simple, relatively inexpensive screening test.  

The most commonly used confirmatory test is Western blot. Western blot demonstrating antibodies to products of all three of the major genes of HIV (gag, pol, and env) is conclusive evidence of infection with HIV. It is considered positive if it shows antibodies against at least two of the following gene products: p24, gp41, gp120/160.
